functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

msg.content: Who are the 5 longest-reigning monarchs and who were their fathers?
Who are the 5 longest-reigning monarchs and who were their fathers?

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions":"Find the 5 longest-reigning monarchs in history and provide the names of their fathers."}

msg.content: Find the names of the fathers of the 5 longest-reigning monarchs in history.

function.name: delegate
function.arguments: {"instructions": "Find the names of the fathers of the 5 longest-reigning monarchs in history."}

msg.content:
<document>
<title>List of longest-reigning monarchs</title>
<fragment>
Monarchs and lifelong leaders who have reigned the longest in world history

For the current reigning monarchs, see List of current reigning monarchs by length of reign.





![](image)
Louis XIV, the longest-reigning sovereign monarch whose reign is verifiable by exact date

This is a list of the **longest-reigning monarchs** of all time, detailing the monarchs and lifelong leaders who have reigned the longest in world history, ranked by length of reign.




## Monarchs of sovereign states with verifiable reigns by exact date[edit]


The following are the 25 longest-reigning monarchs of states who were internationally recognized as sovereign for most or all of their reign. Byzantine emperors Constantine VIII and Basil II, reigning for 66 years in total (962–1028) and for 65 years in total (960–1025) respectively, are not included, because for part of those periods they reigned only nominally as junior co-emperors alongside senior emperors.


</fragment>
<fragment>

These monarchs are grouped according to length of reign by year in whole numbers. Within each year-grouping, they appear in historical order. In a given year, there may have been a wide array of actual reign lengths based on days. Thus, this table does not present a precise ranking by length of reign. The list is limited to those that might reasonably be expected to lie within the range of those in the tables above, at minimum 56 years. The list is sorted alphabetically. ***Emphasised*** states were sovereign. Japanese legendary emperors, according to the ancient Japanese calendar, reigned for very long terms of 60–70 years each. The longest ruler of the legendary emperors, Emperor Kōan, was claimed to have reigned for about 101 years. These figures are not included in the table because they are regarded as inaccurate by modern scholars. For those, see Longevity myths.






</fragment>
<fragment>

## Monarchs of dependent or constituent states with verifiable reigns by exact date[edit]




|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| ![](image)
 | This section **needs additional citations for verification**. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources in this section. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *(June 2021)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)*
 |


The table below contains 100 monarchs of states that were not internationally sovereign for most of their reign. 



![](image)
Sobhuza II, the longest-reigning monarch ever whose reign is verifiable by exact date




</fragment>
<fragment>
| No. | Portrait
 | Name
 | State
 | Reign
 | Duration
 | Ref. |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |

* ![](image) Andorra

 | 72 years, 110 days

| 2

* ![](image) Canada
* ![](image) Australia
* ![](image) New Zealand
[a] | 6 February 1952 | 8 September 2022 | 25,782
 | 70 years, 214 days[b] | [2][3][4] |
| 3
 | ![](image) | Rama IX(Bhumibol Adulyadej) | ![](image) Thailand | 9 June 1946 | 13 October 2016 | 25,694
 | 70 years, 126 days
 | [5] |
| 4

 | 70 years, 91 days
 | [6] |
| 5
 | ![](image) | Kʼinich Janaabʼ Pakal I | Palenque (Mexico)
 | 27 July 615[c] | 29 August 683 | 24,870
 | 68 years, 33 days
 | [7][9] |
| 6
 | ![](image) | Franz Joseph I | * ![](image) Austrian Empire (1848–1867)

</fragment>
<fragment>
51. **^** Sometimes her aunt Anne de La Tour d'Auvergne's death is given as June 1524 or 16 June 1524 (see for example her French wikipedia article), though sources seem to be laking for such specific dates and so she remains here. If sources are found for the 16th of June, she can be moved into the second section with 64 years, 203 days as her reign length
52. **^** [109][110][111]
53. **^** In Co-Reign with his father until 1704
54. **^** Had a interruption between 1818 and 1822 but later regained it in 1822, counting both of his periods he had a reign of 59 years.
55. **^** Disputed name or ruler has two names.
56. **^** He had Regents until 1921.
57. **^** Part of German East Africa from 1890.
58. **^** He also ruled Russia for a brief period between 1068 and 1069.

## References[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
| No. | Portrait
 | Name
 | State
 | Reign
 | Duration
 | Ref. |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| From

 | (days)
 | (years, days)
 |
| 1
 | ![](image) | Sobhuza II[p] | ![](image) Swaziland (British protectorate until 1968)
 | 10 December 1899 | 21 August 1982 | 30,204
 | 82 years, 254 days
 | [38] |
| 2
 | ![](image) | Bernhard VII | ![](image) Lippe (Holy Roman Empire)
 | 11 August 1429 | 2 April 1511 | 29,819
 | 81 years, 234 days
 | [39] |
| 3
 |  | Udai Pratap Nath Shah Deo | Chotanagpur (British Raj)
 | 9 July 1869 | 21 September 1950 | 29,658
 | 81 years, 74 days
 | [40] |
| 4

 | 26 May 1480 | 24 January 1559 | 28,732
 | 78 years, 243 days
 | [39] |
| 5

| 6

</fragment>
<fragment>

Regencies are not counted against monarchs, hence Louis XIV of France being listed first among the monarchs of sovereign states despite his mother Anne of Austria being his regent for 8 years. A distinction is not made between absolute and constitutional monarchy, hence Elizabeth II being listed second despite being a figurehead her entire reign.






</fragment>
<fragment>

1. **^** "BBC – History – Historic Figures: Louis XIV (1638–1715)". *www.bbc.co.uk*. Retrieved 12 April 2020.
2. **^** "Queen Elizabeth II has died, Buckingham Palace announces". *BBC News*. 8 September 2022. Retrieved 8 September 2022.
3. **^** "Her Majesty the Queen". *The Royal Family*. 29 December 2015. Retrieved 6 February 2022.
4. **^** Waites, Rosie (6 February 2012). "The moment a princess became a queen". *BBC News*. Retrieved 10 January 2022.
5. **^** Crossette, Barbara (13 October 2016). "Bhumibol Adulyadej, 88, People's King of Thailand, Dies After 7-Decade Reign". *The New York Times*. ISSN 0362-4331. Retrieved 12 April 2020.
6. **^** "Biographies of the Princes and Princesses". *House of Liechtenstein*.
7. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Pharo, Lars Kirkhusmo (2013). *The Ritual Practice of Time: Philosophy and Sociopolitics of Mesoamerican Calendars*. Brill. p. 92. ISBN 9789004252363.

</fragment>
<fragment>

msg.content: You shouldn't delegate the entire task to a helper. Handle it yourself, or if it's still too complex, try breaking it up into smaller steps and call this again.

<fragment>

Line of succession to the French throne upon the death of Louis XIV in 1715. Louis XIV's only surviving legitimate grandson, Philip V, was not included in the line of succession due to having renounced the French throne after the war of the Spanish Succession, which lasted for 13 years after the death of Charles II of Spain in 1700.[129]

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Johann II, Prince of Liechtenstein</title>
<fragment>

![](image)Formal portrait, 1870
Johann II was the elder son of Aloys II, Prince of Liechtenstein and Countess Franziska Kinsky of Wchinitz and Tettau. He ascended to the throne shortly after his 18th birthday. Until he was surpassed by Elizabeth II on 9 May 2022, his reign had been the longest precisely documented tenure of any European monarch since antiquity in which a regent (that is, a regent serving in place of an underage sovereign) was never employed.[1] Although his mother acted as his regent from 10 February 1859 to November 1860,[2][3] she was not the regent for a minor, but was appointed by her son to fulfil his duties because he wished to finish his education before he began his rule.



## Law and reform[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
Prince of Liechtenstein



| Johann II |
| --- |
| ![](image)Formal portrait, 1928
 |
| Prince of Liechtenstein |
| Reign | 12 November 1858 – 11 February 1929 |
| Predecessor | Aloys II |
| Successor | Franz I |
| Prime Ministers | *See list*

* Karl Freiherr Haus von HausenCarl von In der MaurFriedrich Stellwag von CarionLeopold Freiherr von ImhofMartin RitterPrince Karl Aloys of LiechtensteinJosef PeerJosef OspeltGustav SchädlerJosef Hoop
 |
|  |
| Born | (1840-10-05)5 October 1840Eisgrub, Margraviate of Moravia, Austrian Empire |
| Died | 11 February 1929(1929-02-11) (aged 88)Valtice, First Czechoslovak Republic |
| Burial | Church of the Nativity of the Virgin Mary, Vranov
 |
| 

| Names |
| --- |
| Johann Maria Franz Placidus |

 |
| House | Liechtenstein |
| Father | Aloys II, Prince of Liechtenstein |
| Mother | Countess Franziska Kinsky of Wchinitz and Tettau |


</fragment>
<fragment>

**Johann II** (Johann Maria Franz Placidus; 5 October 1840 – 11 February 1929), nicknamed **the Good** (German: *Johann II. der Gute*), was Prince of Liechtenstein from 12 November 1858 until his death in 1929.


His reign of 70 years and 91 days is the third-longest of any sovereign monarch in European history, after those of Louis XIV and Elizabeth II respectively, and fourth-longest overall for which exact dates are known (after King Louis, Queen Elizabeth, and King Bhumibol Adulyadej respectively).




## Early life[edit]

## External links[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Johann II, an outstanding art connoisseur and a generous patron, added much to the Liechtenstein Princely Collections. Although considered a prominent patron of the arts and sciences during his long reign,[10] Johann II was also considered to be rather unsociable and did not participate in social events. Rarely did he show up in his magnificent Vienna residences, Liechtenstein City Palace and Liechtenstein Garden Palace. He also never assumed any tasks of the Austrian politics or the Austrian military. And he never married or had any children, like several other members of his family.[11]


</fragment>
</document>

<document>
<title>List of longest-reigning monarchs</title>
<fragment>
Monarchs and lifelong leaders who have reigned the longest in world history

For the current reigning monarchs, see List of current reigning monarchs by length of reign.





![](image)
Louis XIV, the longest-reigning sovereign monarch whose reign is verifiable by exact date

This is a list of the **longest-reigning monarchs** of all time, detailing the monarchs and lifelong leaders who have reigned the longest in world history, ranked by length of reign.




## Monarchs of sovereign states with verifiable reigns by exact date[edit]


The following are the 25 longest-reigning monarchs of states who were internationally recognized as sovereign for most or all of their reign. Byzantine emperors Constantine VIII and Basil II, reigning for 66 years in total (962–1028) and for 65 years in total (960–1025) respectively, are not included, because for part of those periods they reigned only nominally as junior co-emperors alongside senior emperors.


</fragment>
<fragment>

These monarchs are grouped according to length of reign by year in whole numbers. Within each year-grouping, they appear in historical order. In a given year, there may have been a wide array of actual reign lengths based on days. Thus, this table does not present a precise ranking by length of reign. The list is limited to those that might reasonably be expected to lie within the range of those in the tables above, at minimum 56 years. The list is sorted alphabetically. ***Emphasised*** states were sovereign. Japanese legendary emperors, according to the ancient Japanese calendar, reigned for very long terms of 60–70 years each. The longest ruler of the legendary emperors, Emperor Kōan, was claimed to have reigned for about 101 years. These figures are not included in the table because they are regarded as inaccurate by modern scholars. For those, see Longevity myths.






</fragment>
<fragment>

## Monarchs of dependent or constituent states with verifiable reigns by exact date[edit]

| --- | --- |
| ![](image)

 |

msg.name: search

msg.content:
Here are the names of the fathers of the 5 longest-reigning monarchs in history:

1. **Louis XIV of France**: His father was [Louis XIII of France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_XIII).
2. **Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom**: Her father was [George VI of the United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_VI).
3. **Bhumibol Adulyadej (Rama IX) of Thailand**: His father was [Mahidol Adulyadej](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahidol_Adulyadej).
4. **Johann II of Liechtenstein**: His father was [Aloys II, Prince of Liechtenstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aloys_II,_Prince_of_Liechtenstein).
5. **K'inich Janaab' Pakal I of Palenque**: His father was K'an Bahlam I.

If you need more detailed information about any of these individuals, feel free to ask!
